Reference¶

Functions¶

Version: 1.0.0 Author: Andreas Helfenstein, andreas.helfenstein@helsinki.fi Last revised: 08-02-2016

class screening_mgmt.screening_mgmt.DbConnection(dialect, host, user, pw, db, driver=None, key_val=None)[source]¶

Interface to the database connection.

Set up connection to a supported SQL database via SQLAlchemy and collect the pointers to the ORM. Initialization of the DbConnection object does not automatically connect to the database.

Parameters:
  • dialect (str) – The database protocol. At the moment, SQLAlchemy supports the following protocols: drizzle, firebird, mssql, mysql, oracle, postgresql, sqlite, and sybase.
  • host (str) – The host (e.g. localhost or 127.0.0.1)
  • user (str) – Username
  • pw (str) – Password
  • db (str) – Database name
  • driver – Driver (default: “”)
  • key_val – Additional key values (default: “”)
Returns:

None
Return type:

None

 
>>> db = DbConnection('mysql', 'localhost', 'user', 'password', 'main')
batch_load(target, delim=', ', raw_file=None, update=False)[source]¶

Load compound and user information from csv file.

Parameters:
  • target (str) – The target data table (e.g. Cpd, Rtn, Usr)
  • delim (str) – Delimiter used in txt and csv files, default is comma (”,”). This value is ignored when reading Excel files.
  • raw_file (str) – Path to the source file. If omitted, it can be chosen via a dialog.
  • update (bool) – If True, existing records will be updated to fit the new data; if False the new records are ignored.
connect()[source]¶

Connect to database, create engine and metadata.

Returns:True if connection is successful
Return type:bool
get_summary(routine, user_dir, df, plot=0, list_=1, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Prepare a summary for .

Parameters:
  • routine (str) – Python script for data import (without file extension). The file must be saved in the user directory.
  • user_dir (str) – Directory of the routine script
  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – The data frame to present, preferably retrieved via load_results().
  • plot (bool) – Return plot
  • list (bool) – Return list
Returns:

{‘list’: <summary as string>, ‘plot’: <matplotlib object>}
Return type:

dict

 
>>> results, dirs = DbConnection.load_results(<filter>, sl=True)
>>> text, img = DbConnection.get_summary('analysis_script', 'user/', results)
>>> print text
>>> img.show()
load_results(filter_str, sl=True, sp=False, dl=False, dp=False)[source]¶

Retrieve data from the database.

Return the filtered data as a pandas data frame. Has to be called for every routine, since data sets from different routines might be in- compatible. :param str filter_str: The filter string (SQLAlchemy syntax) :param bool sl: Save the result as a list :param bool sp: Save the result as a plot :param bool dl: Display the result as a list :param bool dp: Display the result as a plot :return: Tuple of Dataframe with the retrieved results, dict :rtype: Tuple

See also

To learn about SQLAlchemy syntax, refer to their documentation.

new_entry(target, data)[source]¶

Insert a new entry into the target table.

Parameters:
  • target (str) – Name of target database where the record is to be stored.
  • data (dict) – column - value pair. Column names must correspond to columns in the target database, and the data types must be consistent.
 
>>> DbConnection.new_entry({'compound_id': 123,
    'compound_name': 'cpd123', 'MW': 154.2})
update(table, id_field, id_value, val)[source]¶

Update a field in the database.

Parameters:
  • table (str) – Table where the value needs to be updated
  • id_field (str) – Column containing the primary key
  • id_value (str) – Primary key of updated record
  • val (dict) – name-value pairs of column to be updated and new values.
 
>>> # To update the molecular weight of compound 15 in the compound
>>> # table:
>>> DbConnection.update('compound', 'cpd_id', '15', {'mw': 132.5}
write_results(routine, user_dir, preview=False, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Run routine and write the results into the main table.

The function loads the user scripts from the user’s working directory.

Parameters:
  • routine (str) – Python script for data import (without file extension). The file must be saved in the user directory.
  • user_dir (str) – Directory of the routine script
  • preview (bool) – Whether or not to show a preview of the data before writing them to the database
  • kwargs (args,) – Optional arguments for the routine script
Returns:

True in case of success, otherwise false.
Return type:

bool

 
>>> DbConnection.write_results('load_data', 'users/')

See also

On how to write a routine script, refer to the tutorial.
